articles.title: How Our Emotions Contribute to Heart Disease
articles.subtitle: Understanding the crucial link between emotional well-being and heart health
articles.author: Jill Sonlin
articles.excerpt: Did you know that our emotions can also contribute to risks of heart attack and stroke? Understanding this connection is crucial for holistic heart health.
articles.content:
Persuasive emotions that harm

Negative states of mind, including emotions of anger, bitterness, depression, loneliness, and anxiety, can each carry risks of doing a lot of damage to the heart and the body. To lower potential health risks, we must account for and nurish the mind-body connection.

If you are experiencing emotional pain, know that you are not alone.

Seek help to talk about your feelings with a trusted friend, family member, pastor, or therapist. Talking openly about negative feelings can be the start of dealing effectively with and healing emotional burdens of the heart that can affect physical heart health.

articles.title: Stage United Hosts A Night of Song at Tile Works
articles.subtitle: Local musicians gather for a magical evening of storytelling through song
articles.author: Lauren Heine
articles.excerpt: Join in the history of the Tile Works in Doylestown for A Night of Song, a monthly songwriter showcase hosted by Joe Montone, a Bucks County music producer.
articles.content:
A Celebration of Local Talent

The historic Moravian Pottery and Tile Works transforms into an intimate concert venue as Stage United presents its monthly songwriter showcase. Local music producer Joe Montone curates an evening featuring the region's most compelling voices in contemporary folk and acoustic music.

This month's lineup includes emerging artists from across Bucks County, each bringing their unique perspective to the storytelling tradition of folk music. The historic setting of the Tile Works provides perfect acoustics and atmosphere for these intimate performances.

articles.title: Organizational Wisdoms from Wingmoms
articles.subtitle: Finding order in the chaos of family life
articles.author: Natalya Bucuy
articles.excerpt: Nothing is for certain except death and taxes. And laundry. A loyal friend through life's trials, Laundry will always be there for us.
articles.content:
The Art of Family Organization

In the grand symphony of family life, organization is the conductor that keeps everything in harmony. Local moms share their tried-and-true methods for maintaining order in the beautiful chaos of raising children.

From innovative storage solutions to time-management strategies, these Doylestown parents have mastered the art of keeping their households running smoothly while preserving their sanity.

Beyond Basic Organization

The secret, they say, isn't in pursuing perfection but in finding systems that work for your unique family dynamic. These practical solutions have evolved through years of trial and error, resulting in methods that actually stick.

articles.title: “Not If I Can Help It”: Memoir Calls for Justice for Domestic Violence Victims
articles.subtitle: As far as life-changing events go, a 3 a.m. bang on the door resides towards the top of the list. It certainly was so for Meg Groff.
articles.author: Natalya Bucuy
articles.excerpt: In her debut memoir, Not If I Can Help It, A Family Lawyer’s Battles for Justice for Victims of Domestic Violence and the Poor, Meg Groff documents her experiences.
articles.content:
By Natalya Bucuy • Cardinal Managing Editor
As far as life-changing events go, a 3 a.m. bang on the door resides towards the top of the list. It certainly was so for Meg Groff. 
The hysterical night-gowned woman at the door couldn’t even explain her distress until Meg wrapped her in a blanket and held her to calm her down. Then, Lily told the horrific story. Her abusive boyfriend, from whom Lily fled with her newborn baby, found her. He beat her up and drove away in the night with the baby. The police officer on the phone told her there was nothing they could do. Meg suspected miscommunication. But when she called, she got a similar response. A lawyer echoed the police’s sentiments in another call Meg placed the next day. 
The year was 1974. It would be two years before Meg’s native Pennsylvania enacted the Protection from Abuse (PFA) Act, becoming the second state to pass a law in defense of domestic violence victims. People like Lily were out of luck. Meg set out to help. She became a lawyer and an abuse victims’ advocate. She remains one today. 
In her debut memoir, Not If I Can Help It, A Family Lawyer’s Battles for Justice for Victims of Domestic Violence and the Poor, Meg Groff documents her experiences. The book’s pages share Lily’s story among those of dozens of others. Sadly, Meg encountered in her early years as a Bucks County Legal Aid lawyer. For over four decades, Meg defended women and their children against abusive partners, an unfair legal system, and economic injustice. In Lily’s case, things turned out well. The baby was eventually returned to the mother. But many of these stories are sad and tragic. 
The topic on hand is difficult and complex. She engages the reader with tales of creative ways she employed within the system to best serve her clients. Her witty and personal voice takes us through the nightmare world of domestic violence in a way that inspires to act. And that is the goal of the book - to educate readers about the devastating realities of victims. “For years, as a lawyer, I worked to educate the judges, often prejudiced to victims of domestic abuse,” Meg says. “Now, I hope to educate the public. I want people to know that this is not something that happened in the past. It’s happening now. It’s happening in our communities.” 
A natural storyteller, Meg says she always knew she wanted to write and share her client’s stories. She does so beautifully in the book, but her hard work is evident not only in her words but in her stand in the community. 
As I interviewed Meg about her career and the book, I mentioned her name to a friend. Her eyes lit up and then got sad. Lit up, because Meg was her lawyer who saved her life. Sad, because that time of her life was so hard. My friend is among many. Meg encountered and helped countless women and families as a staff lawyer at Bucks County Legal Aid, a volunteer at the local domestic violence organization, the Woman’s Place, and the consultant and strong supporter of Kayden’s Law. 
The latter is a Buck County-based state initiative that gives judges guidance on how to include evidence of domestic violence in their custody judgments. Prior to the law’s enactment in 2024, Groff helped draft the legislation. Following the publishing of her book, she is leading an Impact Campaign to further educate people about Kayden’s law. 
How did this Philadelphia-born hippie who hated school so much that she joined the traffic committee so that she could skip classes turn into a community keystone whose actions save lives?  
That mid-night visitor was Meg’s first encounter with the issue. There would be more night-gowned, bruised women crying in Meg’s arms. A few years later, she finished her degree in psychology - an accomplishment of many years, as Meg took courses for over a decade while also raising a daughter. 
“I had no marketable skills,” Meg writes in the book, describing her unfortunate adventures as a clumsy waitress, a lost taxi-cab driver, and a night industrial sock-machine operator. Eventually, Meg found her way to Temple Law School. There, she felt more out-of-place than ever - everyone had a lawyer connection. She, on the other hand, was a hippie before hippies were in and remained one after, now in the 1980s. But to drop out meant she had to pay back the $5k student loan right away, something she could not afford. And so Meg became a lawyer. Her path took her a to small rural Pennsylvania town and then back to her husband Jim in Bucks County. 
Meg says she also owes her success to her parents. Born in 1943 (something she hopes to change to “something more reasonable.”), Meg lucked out with progressive and supportive parents. They instilled deep values in her, always prioritizing justice and responsibility to help neighbors. It was her mother’s advice to enroll in college that put Meg on her path to her passion for helping people in need. 
Not if I Can Help It is out on March 4 with Rivertowns Publishing. March 4 is also Meg’s birthday. She says she tried to change it once because everyone is miserable in March, asking her friends to instead celebrate her birthday in May. It didn’t stick, but it occurred to Meg that the date precisely stated her life’s purpose. March “Forth.” And so, she does. 
For more information about the book and the Impact Campaign for Kayden’s Law visit, meggroff.com.

articles.title: Beyond Bucks: 10 Winter Road Trip Destinations
articles.subtitle: Winter is the perfect time to embrace the magic of the season with an adventurous road trip
articles.author: Britt Around Town
articles.excerpt: Whether you’re looking to hit the slopes, explore indoor attractions, or just escape the winter “cabin fever,” these ten destinations - all within a roughly 3-hour radius from Bucks County - offer something for everyone.
articles.content:
Winter is the perfect time to embrace the magic of the season with an adventurous road trip. Whether you’re looking to hit the slopes, explore indoor attractions, or just escape the winter “cabin fever,” these ten destinations - all within a roughly 3-hour radius from Bucks County - offer something for everyone. So grab your travel gear, pack some snacks, and get ready to explore.

  1. Elk Mountain Ski Resort – Union Dale, PA

Winter enthusiasts, rejoice! Elk Mountain Ski Resort is a must-visit for anyone craving an authentic skiing experience. Tucked away in Pennsylvania’s Endless Mountains region, this ski resort features 27 trails suited to all skill levels, from gentle greens to daring black diamonds. Known for its exceptional snowmaking and grooming, Elk Mountain has earned its reputation as one of Pennsylvania’s top ski destinations. With stunning views and thrilling slopes, it’s the ideal spot for a day of outdoor adventure.

  1. Kalahari Resort – Pocono Manor, PA

Looking to escape the cold? Step into the year-round tropical paradise of Kalahari Resort. With 220,000 square feet of waterslides, lazy rivers, and wave pools, it’s summer fun all year long. Beyond the waterpark, enjoy mini-golf, bowling, escape rooms, and arcade games. Relax at the spa with a rejuvenating massage or treat yourself to one of the resort’s many dining options. It’s the ultimate getaway for families and fun-seekers alike.

  1. Hershey’s Chocolate World – Hershey, PA

For a sweet escape, head to Hershey’s Chocolate World, where chocolate lovers can surround themselves with all things cocoa. Take the free chocolate factory tour to learn how those iconic Hershey bars are made, complete with a free sample at the end. Afterward, participate in one of Hershey’s Chocolate World’s other activities, including customizing your own candy bar, exploring the candy shop, or joining them on a journey in their new 3D film.

  1. The Hershey Story Museum – Hershey, PA

Just down the road from Chocolate World, The Hershey Story Museum offers a deeper dive into the life and legacy of Milton Hershey. This interactive museum combines history and hands-on fun with exhibits on chocolate-making, philanthropy, and innovation. Kids will love experimenting in the Chocolate Lab, where they can craft their own creations, while adults will appreciate learning about Hershey’s inspiring vision.

  1. LEGOLAND Discovery Center – Plymouth Meeting, PA

Unleash your inner builder at LEGOLAND Discovery Center, an indoor wonderland for LEGO lovers. With themed build zones, interactive rides, and a miniature Philadelphia skyline made entirely of LEGO bricks, this attraction is as creative as it is fun. Younger visitors can explore the DUPLO play area, while the 4D cinema and building challenges keep older kids entertained. It’s a colorful, hands-on adventure perfect for a winter day.

  1. Urban Air Adventure Park – East Norriton, PA

If your kids need to burn off some energy this winter, Urban Air Adventure Park is the place to be. From trampolines and climbing walls to obstacle courses and a thrilling sky coaster, there’s no shortage of activities to keep the whole family moving. This high-energy indoor park is an excellent choice for those seeking excitement and a break from the cold.

  1. Astralumina – Jenkintown, PA

For a truly magical experience, visit Astralumina, an outdoor nighttime light trail in Montgomery County. This enchanting journey blends music, light, and interactive art to transform the forest into a glowing wonderland. Perfect for families or couples, Astralumina offers a unique way to embrace the beauty of winter nights under a dazzling display of creativity.

  1. The Museum at Bethel Woods – Bethel, NY

Nestled in the heart of the Catskill Mountains, The Museum at Bethel Woods offers visitors a journey through the history and culture of the legendary Woodstock Festival. It’s not just about the music—it’s about the movement, the art, and the spirit of the 1960s that shaped a generation. As you walk through the museum’s exhibits, you’ll experience the powerful stories of peace, love, and revolution that define Woodstock. From iconic photographs and original festival memorabilia to interactive displays that highlight the festival’s cultural impact, the museum brings the magic of 1969 to life in a meaningful way. It’s an inspiring visit for anyone who wants to experience the essence of Woodstock and understand its lasting legacy on music, society, and activism.

  1. American Treasure Tour – Oaks, PA

The American Treasure Tour Museum is a hidden gem packed with quirky Americana. This museum houses everything from vintage toys and mechanical music machines to pop culture memorabilia and classic cars. The tram ride through the massive collection is a highlight, offering fun surprises around every corner.

  1. Crayola Experience – Easton, PA

Brighten up a gray winter day at the Crayola Experience, an interactive attraction celebrating creativity and color. Make your own crayon, create spin art, and dive into a world of hands-on activities designed to inspire artists of all ages. With 28 interactive exhibits, it’s a family favorite and a fun way to spend time indoors when the weather turns chilly.
From adrenaline-pumping ski runs to chocolate-filled escapades and luminous nighttime trails, these ten destinations prove there’s no shortage of winter fun near Bucks County. So bundle up, hit the road, and let the season’s adventures unfold.
Britt Around Town takes followers on an experiential journey to hidden treasures throughout Bucks County and beyond."}
